event: denied routinely irrigating or dilating her neovagina
had penetrative sexual intercourse every couple of weeks with her husband
had not had intercourse in a few months
CT imaging of the abdomen demonstrated tubular, heterogenous, fluid-filled structure
outpatient referral to the gynecologist arranged
abdominal pain acutely worsened over the next 24 hours
presented to the local Emergency Department (ED) with diaphoresis
complete blood count (CBC) revealed leukocytosis of 15.6 k/mm3
repeat abdominal CT demonstrated increasing inflammatory process in the pelvis
transferred emergently to our children's hospital
oxygen saturation of 95 % on room air
antimicrobials changed to IV ceftriaxone, IV vancomycin, IV metronidazole
taken emergently to the operative room (OR)
diffuse intra-abdominal spillage of the mucus
one liter of purulent fluid drained
in septic shock requiring three vasopressor agents
antimicrobials transitioned to IV cefepime, IV vancomycin, IV metronidazole
peritoneal cultures finalized to Bacterioides thetaioaomicron, Bacteroides caccae, Actinomyces species
diffuse abdominal pain two weeks post-discharge
CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis showed bilateral pleural effusions
largest next to the liver (15.6 cm)
open anterior midline wound with wound vacuum
transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU)
placement of a right perihepatic drain
drained 350 mL of pus from the right perinephric abscess
drained 90 mL of pus from her perisplenic abscess
broad-spectrum PCR sent on the drained fluid
susceptibilities from the original surgical cultures
broad spectrum PCR positive for Gleimia europaea, Alistipes onderdonkil, Varibaculum timonense, Jonquetella anthropi
followed up at the adult infectious diseases clinic
repeat CT abdomen demonstrated decreased size of right and left sub-phrenic abscesses
transitioned from IV ampicillin-sulbactam to oral amoxicillin-clavulanate
